maml:description.maml:para: List ServiceControl Management Commands
List ServiceControl Management Commands
Add a URLACL reservation to the system.
Adds a URLACL reservation to the system, this action requires Admin privileges. This can be achieved by using NETSH.EXE as well (See related links).
The URL to add to the URLACL list. The parameter must have a trailing slash to be considered valid.
The user or group to assign to this URLACL.
The URL to add to the URLACL list. The parameter must have a trailing slash to be considered valid.
The user or group to assign to this URLACL.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: #Add a URL ACL for the default ServiceControl port Add-UrlAcl -url http://localhost:33333/api/ -users Builtin\Users

maml:description.maml:para: List the currently configured ServiceControl instances.
List the currently configured ServiceControl instances.
Get the Security Identifier (SID) for a User or Group.
Get the Security Identifier (SID) for a User or Group. The cmdlet will process one or more users if passed an array.
Username can be the short name for a local user. e.g Administator Or Username can specified in the longer form which specifies a user belonging to a domain or computer. e.g. MyComputer\Administrator
Username can be the short name for a local user. e.g Administator Or Username can specified in the longer form which specifies a user belonging to a domain or computer. e.g. MyComputer\Administrator

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Get the sid for the Users group Get-SecurityIdentifier Builtin\Users

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Get the sid for the NetworkService Account Get-SecurityIdentifier NetworkService

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Get the sid for the LocalSystem Account Get-SecurityIdentifier System

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Get the sid for the Foo user in MyDomain Get-SecurityIdentifier MyDomain\Foo

maml:description.maml:para: List the currently configured ServiceControl instances.
List the currently configured ServiceControl instances.
Look for ServiceControl Licenses.
Looks for existing ServiceControl License(s) and displays info about it.
List transport types supported by ServiceControl.
List transport types which can be used when setting configuration information in ServiceControl.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # List with more detail Get-ServiceControlTransportTypes | Select -Property *

maml:description.maml:para: List all registered URLACLs.

List all registered URLACLs. The listed entries can be used to diagnose URLACL issues which may prevent ServiceControl from starting. If you require a more feature rich tool for managing URLACLs please take a look at NETSH.EXE.
Imports the Particular Platform License into the Registry.
Imports the Platform License into the Windows Registry for use by ServiceControl.
The path to the license file that will be imported. The license file is written to the following location in the registry: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\ParticularSoftware\License
The path to the license file that will be imported. The license file is written to the following location in the registry: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\ParticularSoftware\License
Upgrade an instance of ServiceControl Monitoring service to the version that shipped with this installation.
Upgrade an instance of ServiceControl Monitoring service to the version that shipped with this installation.
Name of the ServiceControl Monitoring service to upgrade. This corresponds to the Windows Service Name for the service not the Display Name.
Name of the ServiceControl Monitoring service to upgrade. This corresponds to the Windows Service Name for the service not the Display Name.
Normally an instance will attempt to create the queues that it uses. If this flag is set, queue creation will be skipped.
Upgrade an instance of the ServiceControl service to the version that shipped with this installation.
Upgrade an instance of the ServiceControl service to the version that shipped with this installation.

AuditRetentionPeriod controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Audit queue in the database. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 1 hour to 365 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.

ErrorRetentionPeriod controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Error queue in the database. Only error messages that have been successfully retried or marked as resolved are purged. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 10 days to 45 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.
Name of the ServiceControl Service to upgrade. This corresponds to the Windows Service Name for the service not the Display Name.

This parameter is mandatory if the existing instance of ServiceControl does not have an entry in the configuration file for ForwardErrorMessages. When enabled all messages read of the Error queue are forwarded to queue specified ErrorLog queue as part of the import into ServiceControl. This configuration settings did not exist prior to Version of 1.12.

AuditRetentionPeriod controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Audit queue in the database. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 1 hour to 365 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.

ErrorRetentionPeriod controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Error queue in the database. Only error messages that have been successfully retried or marked as resolved are purged. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 10 days to 45 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.
Name of the ServiceControl Service to upgrade. This corresponds to the Windows Service Name for the service not the Display Name.

This parameter is mandatory if the existing instance of ServiceControl does not have an entry in the configuration file for ForwardErrorMessages. When enabled all messages read of the Error queue are forwarded to queue specified ErrorLog queue as part of the import into ServiceControl. This configuration settings did not exist prior to Version of 1.12.
Normally an instance will attempt to create the queues that it uses. If this flag is set, queue creation will be skipped.
Add a new instance of ServiceControl Monitoring service.
Add a new instance of ServiceControl Monitoring service.
The name of the ServiceControl Monitoring instance. This will be used as the Windows Service Name. The name must be unique for all Windows services and not contain any spaces or special characters.
The directory to use for this ServiceControl Monitoring Instance. The binary files are copied here. This directory should be empty or not exist and the path should not be a subfolder of the LogPath
The directory that will contain the logs for this instance of ServiceControl Monitoring. This should be empty or not exist and should not be a subfolder of the InstallPath.

The hostname to use in the URLACL. Values for hostname can be localhost, the fully qualified DNS name fo teh computer or the wildcard character '*'. If localhost is used the URL will only be accessible locally,

The TCP port number to listen on.. The port number must be unique for each instance and not be in use by another process. Use the Test-IfPortIsAvailable cmdlet to verify a port number is free. The allowed port range is 1 to 49151.
Specifies the queue name errors messages are written to

The name of the NServiceBus Transport to use. e.g. "AzureServiceBus", "AzureStorageQueue", "MSMQ", "SQLServer", "AmazonSQS" or "RabbitMQ". Execute 'Get-ServiceControlTransportTypes | Select -Property Name' to retrieve the full list of valid transports.
Specify the Windows Service Display name. If unspecified the instance name will be used.
The connection string to use to connect to the queuing system. This is not required for MSMQ.
Set the optional description on the Windows Service.

The Windows Account to run the service under. Defaults to the LocalSystem account if no account is specified. When specifying Active Directory Group Managed Service Accounts use single quotes so Powershell interprets the dollar sign with the account name as a string literal.
The password for the Service Account. When using LocalSystem, LocalService,, NetworkService or an Active Directory Group Managed Service Account no password should be specified.
Force the installation even if the directories specified are not empty
The name of the ServiceControl Monitoring instance. This will be used as the Windows Service Name. The name must be unique for all Windows services and not contain any spaces or special characters.
The directory to use for this ServiceControl Monitoring Instance. The binary files are copied here. This directory should be empty or not exist and the path should not be a subfolder of the LogPath
The directory that will contain the logs for this instance of ServiceControl Monitoring. This should be empty or not exist and should not be a subfolder of the InstallPath.

The hostname to use in the URLACL. Values for hostname can be localhost, the fully qualified DNS name fo teh computer or the wildcard character '*'. If localhost is used the URL will only be accessible locally,

The TCP port number to listen on.. The port number must be unique for each instance and not be in use by another process. Use the Test-IfPortIsAvailable cmdlet to verify a port number is free. The allowed port range is 1 to 49151.
Specifies the queue name errors messages are written to

The name of the NServiceBus Transport to use. e.g. "AzureServiceBus", "AzureStorageQueue", "MSMQ", "SQLServer" or "RabbitMQ". Execute 'Get-ServiceControlTransportTypes | Select -Property Name' to retrieve the full list of valid transports.
Specify the Windows Service Display name. If unspecified the instance name will be used.
The connection string to use to connect to the queuing system. This is not required for MSMQ.
Set the optional description on the Windows Service.

The Windows Account to run the service under. Defaults to the LocalSystem account if no account is specified. When specifying Active Directory Group Managed Service Accounts use single quotes so Powershell interprets the dollar sign with the account name as a string literal.
The password for the Service Account. When using LocalSystem, LocalService,, NetworkService or an Active Directory Group Managed Service Account no password should be specified.
Normally an instance will attempt to create the queues that it uses. If this flag is set, queue creation will be skipped.
Force the installation even if the directories specified are not empty
Add a new instance of ServiceControl service.
Add a new instance of ServiceControl and registers it as Windows Service.
The name of the ServiceControl instance. This will be used as the Windows Service Name. The name must be unique for all Windows services and not contain any spaces or special characters.
The directory to use for this ServiceControl Instance. The binary files are copied here. This directory should be empty or not exist and the path should not be a subfolder of the DBPath or LogPath

The directory that will contain the embedded database files for this ServiceControl Instance. This should be unique for each instance of ServiceControl and should not be a subfolder of the InstallPath or LogPath.
The directory that will contain the logs for this instance of ServiceControl. This should be empty or not exist and should not be a subfolder of the InstallPath.

The hostname to use in the URLACL. Values for hostname can be localhost, the fully qualified DNS name fo teh computer or the wildcard character '*' . If localhost is used the URL will only be accessible locally, WARNING: The default value is localhost. Consider carefully the implications of exposing ServiceControl via a custom or wildcard URL. There is no inbuilt security so all messages stroed will be accessable using anonymous access.

The TCP port number to listen on. If this is the only ServiceControl instance then 33333 is recommended. The port number must be unique for each instance and not be in use by another process. Use the Test-IfPortIsAvailable cmdlet to verify a port number is free. The allowed port range is 1 to 49151.
Specifies the input queue name to consume error messages from.
Specifies the input queue name to consume audit messages from.
The queue that error messages will be forwarded to if ForwardErrorMessages is enabled. See ForwardErrorMessages for more information.
The queue that audit messages will be forwarded to if ForwardAuditMessages is enabled. See ForwardAuditMessages for more information.

The name of the NServiceBus Transport to use. e.g. "AzureServiceBus", "AzureStorageQueue", "MSMQ", "SQLServer" or "RabbitMQ". Execute 'Get-ServiceControlTransportTypes | Select -Property Name' to retrieve the full list of valid transports.
Specify the Windows Service Display name. If unspecified the instance name will be used.
DEPRECATED. Optional Virtual directory name. Not recommended, this is retained for legacy configuration purposes.
The connection string to use to connect to the queuing system. This is not required for MSMQ.
Set the optional description on the Windows Service.

When enabled the audit forwarding queue retains a copy of the original messages ingested by ServiceControl. Forwarding queues are not directly managed by ServiceControl and are meant as points of external integration. If external integration is not required, it is highly recommend to turn forwarding off. Otherwise, messages will accumulate unprocessed in the forwarding queue until eventually all available disk space is consumed.

When enabled the error forwarding queue retains a copy of the original messages ingested by ServiceControl. Forwarding queues are not directly managed by ServiceControl and are meant as points of external integration. If external integration is not required, it is highly recommend to turn forwarding off. Otherwise, messages will accumulate unprocessed in the forwarding queue until eventually all available disk space is consumed.

The Windows Account to run the service under. Defaults to the LocalSystem account if no account is specified. When specifying Active Directory Group Managed Service Accounts use single quotes so Powershell interprets the dollar sign with the account name as a string literal.
The password for the Service Account. When using LocalSystem, LocalService,, NetworkService or an Active Directory Group Managed Service Account no password should be specified.

AuditRetention Period controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Audit queue in the database. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 1 hour to 365 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.

ErrorRetentionPeriod controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Error queue in the database. The retention policy does not remove error messages that still in the unresolved state. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 10 days to 45 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.
Force the installation even if the directories specified are not empty
The name of the ServiceControl instance. This will be used as the Windows Service Name. The name must be unique for all Windows services and not contain any spaces or special characters.
The directory to use for this ServiceControl Instance. The binary files are copied here. This directory should be empty or not exist and the path should not be a subfolder of the DBPath or LogPath

The directory that will contain the embedded database files for this ServiceControl Instance. This should be unique for each instance of ServiceControl and should not be a subfolder of the InstallPath or LogPath.
The directory that will contain the logs for this instance of ServiceControl. This should be empty or not exist and should not be a subfolder of the InstallPath.

The hostname to use in the URLACL. Values for hostname can be localhost, the fully qualified DNS name fo teh computer or the wildcard character '*' . If localhost is used the URL will only be accessible locally, WARNING: The default value is localhost. Consider carefully the implications of exposing ServiceControl via a custom or wildcard URL. There is no inbuilt security so all messages stroed will be accessable using anonymous access.

The TCP port number to listen on. If this is the only ServiceControl instance then 33333 is recommended. The port number must be unique for each instance and not be in use by another process. Use the Test-IfPortIsAvailable cmdlet to verify a port number is free. The allowed port range is 1 to 49151.
Specifies the input queue name to consume error messages from.
Specifies the input queue name to consume audit messages from.
The queue that error messages will be forwarded to if ForwardErrorMessages is enabled. See ForwardErrorMessages for more information.
The queue that audit messages will be forwarded to if ForwardAuditMessages is enabled. See ForwardAuditMessages for more information.

The name of the NServiceBus Transport to use. e.g. "AzureServiceBus", "AzureStorageQueue", "MSMQ", "SQLServer" or "RabbitMQ". Execute 'Get-ServiceControlTransportTypes | Select -Property Name' to retrieve the full list of valid transports.
Specify the Windows Service Display name. If unspecified the instance name will be used.
DEPRECATED. Optional Virtual directory name. Not recommended, this is retained for legacy configuration purposes.
The connection string to use to connect to the queuing system. This is not required for MSMQ.
Set the optional description on the Windows Service.

When enabled the audit forwarding queue retains a copy of the original messages ingested by ServiceControl. Forwarding queues are not directly managed by ServiceControl and are meant as points of external integration. If external integration is not required, it is highly recommend to turn forwarding off. Otherwise, messages will accumulate unprocessed in the forwarding queue until eventually all available disk space is consumed.

When enabled the error forwarding queue retains a copy of the original messages ingested by ServiceControl. Forwarding queues are not directly managed by ServiceControl and are meant as points of external integration. If external integration is not required, it is highly recommend to turn forwarding off. Otherwise, messages will accumulate unprocessed in the forwarding queue until eventually all available disk space is consumed.

The Windows Account to run the service under. Defaults to the LocalSystem account if no account is specified. When specifying Active Directory Group Managed Service Accounts use single quotes so Powershell interprets the dollar sign with the account name as a string literal.
The password for the Service Account. When using LocalSystem, LocalService,, NetworkService or an Active Directory Group Managed Service Account no password should be specified.

AuditRetention Period controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Audit queue in the database. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 1 hour to 365 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.

ErrorRetentionPeriod controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Error queue in the database. The retention policy does not remove error messages that still in the unresolved state. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 10 days to 45 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.
Normally an instance will attempt to create the queues that it uses. If this flag is set, queue creation will be skipped.
Force the installation even if the directories specified are not empty

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
$AuditRetention = New-TimeSpan -Days 30 $ErrorRetention = New-TimeSpan -Days 30
New-ServiceControlInstance -Name 'ServiceControlTest' ` -InstallPath 'c:\bin\ServiceControlProd' ` -DBPath 'c:\data\ServiceControlProd\DB' ` -LogPath 'c:\data\ServiceControlProd\Logs' ` -HostName 'localhost' ` -Port 33333 ` -ErrorQueue error ` -AuditQueue audit ` -Transport MSMQ ` -DisplayName 'ServiceControl Test' ` -AuditRetentionPeriod $AuditRetention ` -ErrorRetentionPeriod $ErrorRetention ` -ForwardAuditMessages:$false ` -ForwardErrorMessages:$false

dev:remarks.maml:para:
WARNING: ServiceAccountset to default value 'LocalSystem' VERBOSE: Installing Service Control instance...
Name : ServiceControlTest Url : http://localhost:33335/api/ HostName : localhost Port : 33331 InstallPath : c:\bin\ServiceControlProd DBPath : c:\data\ServiceControlProd\DB LogPath : c:\data\ServiceControlProd\Logs TransportPackage : MSMQ ConnectionString : ErrorQueue : error ErrorLogQueue : error.log AuditQueue : audit AuditLogQueue : audit.log ForwardAuditMessages : False ForwardErrorMessages : False ServiceAccount : LocalSystem Version : 1.33.0

maml:description.maml:para: Create an instance from an unattended install file.
Create an instance from an unattended install file. The unattended install file can be made using the New-ServiceControlUnattendedFile cmdlet.
The path the the unattended xml file to process.

The Windows Account to run the service under. Defaults to the LocalSystem account if no account is specified. When specifying Active Directory Group Managed Service Accounts use single quotes so Powershell interprets the dollar sign with the account name as a string literal.
The password for the Service Account. When using LocalSystem, LocalService,, NetworkService or an Active Directory Group Managed Service Account no password should be specified.
Force the installation even if the directories specified are not empty.
The path the the unattended xml file to process.

The Windows Account to run the service under. Defaults to the LocalSystem account if no account is specified. When specifying Active Directory Group Managed Service Accounts use single quotes so Powershell interprets the dollar sign with the account name as a string literal.
The password for the Service Account. When using LocalSystem, LocalService,, NetworkService or an Active Directory Group Managed Service Account no password should be specified.
Force the installation even if the directories specified are not empty.

maml:alert.maml:para: DEPRECATED - This Cmdlet will be removed in a future version. To automate an installation the preferred approach is to use a New-ServiceControlInstance instead of the unattended install file.

maml:description.maml:para: Create an instance from an unattended install file. DEPRECATED - This Cmdlet will be removed in a future version. To automate an installation the preferred approach is to use a New-ServiceControlInstance instead of the unattended install fle.

Create an instance from an unattended install file. The resultant XML file can be passed to the ServiceControl Installation executable using the UNATTENDEDFILE command line option. An instance can also me made from the file by using the New-ServiceControlInstanceFromUnattendedFile cmdlet.
The name of the ServiceControl Instance. This will be used as the Windows Service Name. The name must be unique for all Windows services and not contain any spaces or special characters.
The directory to use for this ServiceControl Instance. The binary files are copied here.
The directory that will contain the embedded database files for this ServiceControl Instance.
The directory that will contain the logs for this instance of ServiceControl. This should be unique for each instance of ServiceControl and should not be a subfolder of the InstallPath or DBPath.

The hostname to use in the URLACL (defaults to localhost). Anyone who can access the ServiceControl URL has complete access to the message data stored within ServiceControl. This is why the default is to only respond to the localhost. Consider carefully the implications of exposing ServiceControl via a custom or wildcard URL.

The TCP port number to listen on. If this is the only ServiceControl instance then 33333 is recommended. The port number must be unique for each instance and not be in use by another process. Use the Test-IfPortIsAvailable cmdlet to verify a port number is free. The allowed port range is 1 to 49151.
Specifies the input queue name to consume error messages from.
Specifies the input queue name to consume audit messages from.
The queue that error messages will be forwarded to if ForwardErrorMessages is enabled. See ForwardErrorMessages for more information
The queue that audit messages will be forwarded to if ForwardAuditMessages is enabled. See ForwardAuditMessages for more information

The name of the NServiceBus Transport to use. e.g. "AzureServiceBus", "AzureStorageQueue", "MSMQ", "SQLServer" or "RabbitMQ". Execute 'Get-ServiceControlTransportTypes | Select -Property Name' to retrieve the full list of valid transports.
Specify the Windows Service Display name. If unspecified the instance name will be used.
DEPRECATED. Optional Virtual directory name. Not recommended, this is retained for legacy configuration purposes.
The connection string to use to connect to the queuing system. This is not required for MSMQ.
Set the optional description on the Windows Service.

When enabled the audit forwarding queue retains a copy of the original messages ingested by ServiceControl. Forwarding queues are not directly managed by ServiceControl and are meant as points of external integration. If external integration is not required, it is highly recommend to turn forwarding off. Otherwise, messages will accumulate unprocessed in the forwarding queue until eventually all available disk space is consumed.

When enabled the error forwarding queue retains a copy of the original messages ingested by ServiceControl. Forwarding queues are not directly managed by ServiceControl and are meant as points of external integration. If external integration is not required, it is highly recommend to turn forwarding off. Otherwise, messages will accumulate unprocessed in the forwarding queue until eventually all available disk space is consumed.

AuditRetention Period controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Audit queue in the database. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 1 hour to 365 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.

ErrorRetentionPeriod controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Error queue in the database. The retention policy does not remove error messages that still in the unresolved state. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 10 days to 45 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.
Specifies the path of the XML output file.
The name of the ServiceControl Instance. This will be used as the Windows Service Name. The name must be unique for all Windows services and not contain any spaces or special characters.
The directory to use for this ServiceControl Instance. The binary files are copied here.
The directory that will contain the embedded database files for this ServiceControl Instance.
The directory that will contain the logs for this instance of ServiceControl. This should be unique for each instance of ServiceControl and should not be a subfolder of the InstallPath or DBPath.

The hostname to use in the URLACL (defaults to localhost). Anyone who can access the ServiceControl URL has complete access to the message data stored within ServiceControl. This is why the default is to only respond to the localhost. Consider carefully the implications of exposing ServiceControl via a custom or wildcard URL.

The TCP port number to listen on. If this is the only ServiceControl instance then 33333 is recommended. The port number must be unique for each instance and not be in use by another process. Use the Test-IfPortIsAvailable cmdlet to verify a port number is free. The allowed port range is 1 to 49151.
Specifies the input queue name to consume error messages from.
Specifies the input queue name to consume audit messages from.
The queue that error messages will be forwarded to if ForwardErrorMessages is enabled. See ForwardErrorMessages for more information
The queue that audit messages will be forwarded to if ForwardAuditMessages is enabled. See ForwardAuditMessages for more information

The name of the NServiceBus Transport to use. e.g. "AzureServiceBus", "AzureStorageQueue", "MSMQ", "SQLServer" or "RabbitMQ". Execute 'Get-ServiceControlTransportTypes | Select -Property Name' to retrieve the full list of valid transports.
Specify the Windows Service Display name. If unspecified the instance name will be used.
DEPRECATED. Optional Virtual directory name. Not recommended, this is retained for legacy configuration purposes.
The connection string to use to connect to the queuing system. This is not required for MSMQ.
Set the optional description on the Windows Service.

When enabled the audit forwarding queue retains a copy of the original messages ingested by ServiceControl. Forwarding queues are not directly managed by ServiceControl and are meant as points of external integration. If external integration is not required, it is highly recommend to turn forwarding off. Otherwise, messages will accumulate unprocessed in the forwarding queue until eventually all available disk space is consumed.

When enabled the error forwarding queue retains a copy of the original messages ingested by ServiceControl. Forwarding queues are not directly managed by ServiceControl and are meant as points of external integration. If external integration is not required, it is highly recommend to turn forwarding off. Otherwise, messages will accumulate unprocessed in the forwarding queue until eventually all available disk space is consumed.

AuditRetention Period controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Audit queue in the database. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 1 hour to 365 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.

ErrorRetentionPeriod controls how long ServiceControl retains messages ingested from the Error queue in the database. The retention policy does not remove error messages that still in the unresolved state. The value must be a TimeSpan within the range 10 days to 45 days. Use the New-TimeSpan cmdlet to generate a TimeSpan value.
Specifies the path of the XML output file.
Removes a instance of ServiceControl Monitoring service.
Removes an instance of ServiceControl Monitoring service for the list of running services and deletes the bin folder. The logs folder can also be removed
Name of the ServiceControl Monitoting service to remove. This corresponds to the Windows Service Name for the service not the Display Name.
Remove the contents of the Log folder as part of the instance removal
Name of the ServiceControl Monitoting service to remove. This corresponds to the Windows Service Name for the service not the Display Name.
Remove the contents of the Log folder as part of the instance removal
Removes a instance of ServiceControl service.
Removes an instance of ServiceControl service for the list of running services and deletes the bin folder. The logs and RavenDB folders can also be removed
Name of the ServiceControl Service to remove. This corresponds to the Windows Service Name for the service not the Display Name.
Remove the contents of the Database folder.
Remove the contents of the Log folder.
Name of the ServiceControl Service to remove. This corresponds to the Windows Service Name for the service not the Display Name.
Remove the contents of the Database folder.
Remove the contents of the Log folder.
Removes a URLACL.
Removes a URLACL Registration form the list of URLACLs.
The URLACL to remove. The current URLACLs can be obtained from Get-URLACLs.
The URLACL to remove. The current URLACLs can be obtained from Get-URLACLs.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Remove all URLACLs assigned to port 33333 Get-UrlAcls | ? Port -EQ 33333 | Remove-UrlACl

maml:description.maml:para: Check a TCP port number to see if it is already in by a running process.
Check a TCP port number to see if it is already in use by a running process.
The port number to check. Must be between 1 and 65535.
The port number to check. Must be between 1 and 65535.
